name: betula-lenta
wildlife-value: It is a larval host plant for the Mourning Cloak and Dreamy Duskywing butterflies. You may see  Mourning Cloak (Nymphalis antiopa) which has one flight from June-July, Dreamy Duskywing (Erynnis icelus) with one brood April-July and rarely a second in the south, and Eastern Tiger Swallowtail (Papilo glaucus) which has three flights from February-November in the south and two flights May-September in the north. Many moths also use as a host plant. Its seeds are eaten by birds.
particularly-resistant-to-insects/diseas: highly deer resistant; Fire in the landscape.
edibility: Sap has been used for syrup and brewed into beer; however, oil from the bark can be toxic.
light: Deep shade (Less than 2 hours to no direct sunlight)
Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: This plants' seed is a nutlet. During summer, 1 to 1.5-inch oblong, erect cones ripen and break apart, exposing the 2 very small, winged nutlets.
flower-description: The Sweet Birch has small green flowers that are tinged with red and mature in early spring. The flower on the Sweet birch has 3" to 4" male catkins.
leaf-description: The leaves of the Sweet Birch are 2.5" to 6", broad, ovate with cordate base, single-toothed margins, alternate and simple. Leaves turn a golden-yellow color in the fall.
bark-description: The bark of young trees isÂ smooth, breaking into small chip-like plates as it ages. Dark, shiny, tight bark with horizontal lenticels. Crushed twigs smell like wintergreen.
uses: This plant is used in the production of wintergreen oil. In the past, the people of the Appalachians cut large numbers of this tree to produce wintergreen oil. 100 saplings and young trees were needed to produce only a quart of the oil. The hard, close grained lumber is used for furniture and interior trims.
